title: Manchester United coaches fearful over club’s young stars during crisis
text:
Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is under pressure (Picture: Getty Images)

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s backroom staff are concerned over the future of Manchester United’s talented young stars, fearing their development could be seriously harmed by the club’s struggles.

Solskjaer has shown plenty of faith in academy graduates this season, hailing 18-year-old Mason Greenwood as ‘one of the best finishers I have seen’, while giving opportunities to the likes of Tahith Chong, Angel Gomes and Brandon Williams.

But there are fears that throwing them in at the deep end during a time where United are in crisis could have long-term adverse effects.

Solskjaer has put faith in young players like Greenwood (Picture: Getty Images)

United’s coaching staff have looked at the success of Chelsea’s yong players this season and believe the likes of Tammy Abraham, Mason Mount and Fikayo Tomori have all benefited from multiple loan spells away from Stamford Bridge before shouldering the responsibility of starring for one of the biggest clubs on the planet.

Abraham has bagged eight Premier League goals this season and is just four weeks older than Marcus Rashford, who has been forced to bear the brunt of the weight of attacking expectations almost solely on his young shoulders this season.

There is a fear among the backroom staff that United’s crop of young players will get so used to losing that it will become a habit that’s difficult to break, according to the BBC.

United currently sit 12th in the Premier League, two points above the relegation zone, having won just two of their opening eight league matches.

It is possible they could find themselves in the relegation zone after the next round of fixtures after the international break. They take on league leaders Liverpool at Old Trafford.
